title: Synthetic Recap
body:
EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. (AP) — The numbers on the scoresheet read like a misprint, a line so dominant it felt plucked from a bygone era. But for the 1998 New Jersey Nets and the Milwaukee Bucks, the historic performance by Jayson Williams was a brutal, beautiful reality.

In a gritty 112-104 victory, Williams wasn't just a player; he was an elemental force. The Nets’ center authored a performance for the ages, hauling down a staggering **28 rebounds** to go with his 22 points. He was an immovable object on the glass, relentlessly outmuscling and out-hustling the entire Bucks roster. Every Milwaukee miss seemed to end up in his grasp, fueling the New Jersey offense and systematically breaking the visitors’ spirit.

While Williams commanded the paint, teammate Kendall Gill provided the piercing offensive thrust, slashing his way to a game-high **32 points**. His scoring was the perfect complement to Williams’ interior tyranny, ensuring the Nets’ effort was balanced and lethal. Kerry Kittles added a vital 19 points, but the night belonged to the man in the middle.

Milwaukee fought valiantly, led by Terrell Brandon’s 26 points and sharp 10-assist playmaking. Glenn Robinson added 21 points, but the Bucks simply had no answer for the Williams-led rebounding onslaught. They were systematically dismantled on the boards, a fundamental failing that no amount of scoring could overcome.

In the end, the final score was almost a footnote. The real story was written in the rebound column, a testament to one man’s relentless will. On this night, Jayson Williams didn’t just win a game; he owned it, delivering a rebounding clinic that will echo through the franchise’s history.
